title: Fire Cancelled events from SKTouchHandler.Reset() when needed
body:
**Description of Change**

Touches are now tracked in `SKTouchHandler`. For all touches that aren't Ended or Cancelled by the time `Reset()` is called, the `Reset()` method fires `SKTouchAction.Cancelled` events. This fixes `SKTouchAction.Cancelled` not getting sent when the user scrolls.

https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/uigesturerecognizer/1620004-reset

There could potentially be a better way of doing this without a `HashSet`, but this is the only method that I have found to work just like the other platforms.

**Bugs Fixed**

- #1048

**API Changes**

None

**Behavioral Changes**

When the iOS gesture recognizer is Reset (commonly due to the user scrolling a view), the `SKTouchAction.Cancelled` touch event will now be received.
